data.title: Hypnos, Greek God of Sleep, bronze head from a statue, 3rd cent BC
data.meta_description:
Hypnos (Somnus), god of sleep in Greek mythology, was thought of in antiquity as a winged youth who touches the foreheads of the tired with a branch, or pours sleep-inducing liquid from a horn (Vergil, Aeneid 5. 854).
	
	Here, wings sprout from the side of his head and his hair flows freely behind.
	
	Hellenistic (or Roman copy), from Umbria, Italy c.350-200 BC
	
	The British Museum, London UK.
data.text:
Hypnos (Somnus), god of sleep in Greek mythology, was thought of in antiquity as a winged youth who touches the foreheads of the tired with a branch, or pours sleep-inducing liquid from a horn (Vergil, Aeneid 5. 854).

Here, wings sprout from the side of his head and his hair flows freely behind.

Hellenistic (or Roman copy), from Umbria, Italy c.350-200 BC

The British Museum, London UK.
